ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: General overview of the some of the largest ancient cities in which archaeologists are interested in. Introduction to some field methods and larger, field-wide problems.

One skill that I think is amazing to have learned through this course is being able to write so much about a single object. The best parts of the class is the labs. In the labs, I was able to write and interpret objects, being able to be imaginitive and taking small details to draw a larger story. It was a strong introduction to the archaeological methods. As a student interested in archaeology, I believe it was a strong introductory course.
This was a great introduction to the field of archaeology.

This course taught me fundamental archaeology methods (dating, analyzing artifacts, surveying sites, etc.) and provided a fascinating survey of archaeological research across the world. Not only did I learn more about civilizations I knew about (e.g., Mesopotamia), but also about places with new archaeological research, such as the Polynesian Islands.
I developed knowledge on many different ancient civilizations around the world, many of whom I had never heard of before. I also developed skills that helped me analyze ancient artifacts.
Learned a lot of unique skills and information about archaeology in general.
This course gives students a great basic understanding of archaeological skills and an insight into multiple civilizations.
I learned how to discuss and think about the basic principles of archaeology. I gained and overarching knowledge of the discipline on a global scale.
I learned about the archaeological techniques used to study ancient societies all over the world.
survey of ancient world
I learned about ancient civilizations and archaeological methods.
In this course we learned a very broad introductory to the field of archaeology.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Anne is a great lecturer and the class was super engaging. She made sure to learn our names and interact with us despite the course format. Assignments weren't too difficult and TF feedback was super detailed and helpful. Most assignments were in pairs, which I really enjoyed. 
Weaknesses: Some assignments had vague directions. For example, the paper prompt was just to evaluate a popular archaeology story. Many of us kinda struggled to find some direction from that.

I found the course schedule to work really well. The combination of integrating the lab component into the weekly class schedule (and then also scheduling most of the work towards the beginning and middle of the semester), made the whole course feel more manageable. 

The in-class discussions/debates were also very helpful to flesh out some of the concepts from the lectures.

One weakness that I am unsure how this could be avoided due to its intergral nature to the course is the quick passing between different civilizations. It is difficuult to draw a continuity between the weeks and lectures because of how diverse the content is. I think it is good that we are exposed to different areas. But I wonder if it is possible to make more clear connections between the topics. Perhaps, more emphasis on building understandings about civilizations in general.
I think one strength of this class is the mix of lectures, labs, projects, and essays. It kept the class engaging and was especially appropriate for the subject matter.
Great lectures with an excellent professor

Strengths: fascinating lectures, very committed professor and teaching assistants, enjoyable and educational labs, coursework is spread out evenly over the semester
Weaknesses: It would have been helpful to have a rubric to know what types of things the instructors were looking for in grading papers and lab assignments.

The strengths of this course are the lab exercises, which are very interesting and cool. Additionally, the professor is very engaging and kind. But, the course tries to cover too much material with 3 classes a week and discussing a new civilization essentially every class. I wish the numbers of civilizations was cut down in order to focus in on them.
I enjoyed the lab opportunities in which this class gave to students
i enjoyed the labs and the hand on activities, however i wish there was more student engagement during the lectures.
Not super engaging lectures, really interesting labs.
I did not love the lectures and I wish the slides would have been posted on Canvas to use for studying.
good lectures, wish powerpoints were posted

I would like to see a more comprehensive history curriculum. I understand it is an archaeology course, and it does very well at being an archaeology course, but I think it would make it more engaging and more relevant if there was a greater attempt to connect the archaeology with more comprehensive "history" lessons

I really enjoyed the labs and write ups, the material was fascinating, and the professor and the TAs were very accessible and helpful. I wish lecture slides had been posted after class, and I wish there had been more clarity surrounding instructions, especially for major assignments.
The course had a very reasonable workload. The course could be improved if the lectures were not so similar. While the material would be different, they felt very much the same.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they are interested in archaeology and getting an overview of major research areas, then absolutely! However, if archaeology isn't really their thing, I am not sure if they would be too interested or engaged in this course.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, because Dr. Underhill and the TAs provide substantial insight into the topic. Additionally, truly care about each individual student.
I would recommend this course to anyone who has any interest in archaeology. It is a great survey and introduction.

Yes! I learned so much about archaeological methods, world history, and the frontiers of archaeological research. Professor Underhill is very committed to the course and the lectures are fascinating. The labs are enjoyable and allow you to gain hands-on experience with archaeology, and the class discussions facilitate deep thinking about the topics.
Yes.
I would recommend this class to another student because the workload is light and the material is very interesting.
Yes, great professor that made class more enjoyable.
i would only recommend this course to students interested in the archaeology and/or anthropology major. Otherwise, I am unsure that the student would be as engaged in the material.
Yes it was a good course and had a lot of good information
If they find archeological studies to be a riveting subject for them, then I would recommend this class. Otherwise, I would not recommend this class.
Yes, very good survey of ancient world with courseload that isn't too heavy!

I would recommend this course to a student interested in learning about ancient civilizations, as well as students looking for a good introduction to archaeology. I was not familiar with the field when I first started the course, but I now have a solid basic understanding of archaeological methodology.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in history or archaeology.
